Award.AwardTitle: DUSEL R&D: Fast Neutron Spectroscopy in the Deep Underground Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop a spectrometer to detect fast neutrons which will allow the characterization of the background environment for sensitive underground experiments. These experiments, such as searches for WIMP dark matter, neutrinoless double beta decay, and detection of solar neutrinos, are some of the highest priority directions in nuclear and particle physics, and understanding the backgrounds in which they must operate is essential to their success.
The spectrometer proposed here will use a technique called capture-gated spectroscopy, with a lithium-loaded liquid scintillator, and will be able to measure both the fluence and energy of neutrons up to 50 MeV.
This technique also has important applications in homeland security and neutron dosimetry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Precise knowledge of the fast neutron spectrum and fluence is essential for several experimental endeavors requiring the low-background of the underground ground environment.  These experiments include some of the most important directions in nuclear and particle physics that are under consideration for underground laboratories world-wide, such as searches for dark matter, neutrinoless double beta decay, and solar neutrinos.  In recent years, the need for sensitive measurements of fast neutron fluxes and energy spectra has outpaced the ability to perform such measurements. Thus, new instruments and techniques are being developed to meet the needs of these experiments and advance the ability to characterize the fast neutron backgrounds.

 

The University of Maryland and the National Institute of Standards and Technology developed a program for improving fast neutron detection and spectroscopy. The basic principle involved using a volume of liquid scintillator to detector fast neutrons through their recoil interaction with protons in the scintillator. The neutrons thermalize and are captured, thus producing a signal indicating that the recoil event was due to a neutron. This capture serves to discriminate against background events. Three separate spectrometers using this detection principle were investigated, each accenting different capabilities. The first was a high-resolution spectrometer containing 16 segments of liquid scintillator developed in collaboration with Russian researchers at the Institute for Nuclear Research. The size of the 16 segments was chosen so that a fast neutron interacts on average only once in a segment, thus allowing one to correct for the nonlinear light yield, which is the dominant cause of poor energy resolution. A method for doping liquid scintillator with Li-6 to capture the thermalized neutron was developed for use in this spectrometer.

 

A larger volume detector was used on the surface and in the underground environment where high efficiency is more important that energy resolution. This prototype fast neutron spectrometer (FaNS-1) was constructed and measured the fast neutron spectrum at the Earth’s surface, and it was also deployed at Kimballton Underground Research Facility near Blacksburg, VA. It consists of He-3 proportional counters placed between blocks of plastic scintillator. It acquired data on the fast neutron flux underground for about two years until 2012. Using knowledge gained from FaNS-1, a second larger-volume detector (FaNS-2) was constructed with a greater sensitivity to the high-energy component of the fast neutron flux induced by cosmic rays. The spectrometer consists of bars of plastic scintillator interspersed with He-3 tubes, and it has energy sensitivity from about 1 MeV to a few GeV. FaNS-2 measured the surface spectrum with higher precision, and it is currently measuring the fast neutrons in a shallow underground location. After the completion of this measurement, it will be available for deployment to other underground locations for the characterization of the fast neutron backgrounds.
